Award.AwardTitle: High Resolution Functional Genomics of Fleshy Fruit Development and Environmental Responses
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Jocelyn K.C. Rose (Cornell University)

CoPIs: Carmen Catala and Zhangjun Fei (Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research) and James J. Giovannoni (USDA-ARS/Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research)

Fleshy fruit are unique plant developmental systems and provide important components of human and animal diets. Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum), an economically important crop, has emerged as the principal model for studies of fleshy fruit development, ripening, shelf life and nutritional quality. However, many fundamental questions related to key aspects of the development, physiology, quality traits and environmental responses of fleshy fruit remain unanswered. This project will decipher complex problems in plant biology that are also central to fleshy fruit development and quality: (i) the regulatory processes that influence fruit growth and ripening; (ii) the associated hormone biosynthesis and signaling pathways; and (iii) molecular events that result in cell wall formation and restructuring, and that provide protection from environmental stresses. An important element of this project is the development of a strong education and training component. This will take the form of two programs: (1) an annual Plant Genomics and Systems Biology Workshop, comprising a series of integrated 'technology modules' with both seminars and lab-based practical training in 'omics disciplines'; (2) a multi-level training course in Scientific Communication, providing guidance in both oral and written presentation skills. These will be affiliated with undergraduate students, high school students and high school teachers, with particular emphasis on the participation of under-represented groups through the support of a network of existing Cornell programs.

Studies to date have provided valuable initial insights into the identity and temporal expression patterns of some of the genes that regulate fruit development; however, they have almost exclusively used total tomato fruit pericarp ('flesh') and have largely ignored spatial variation in global gene expression in the different constituent cell types. The goal of this project is to extend these studies to characterize the responses of fruits to drought, an increasing problem in crop production, in tomato using cutting edge genomics technologies. These studies will be extended to two diverse wild relatives of tomato that show a high tolerance of water stress, and so may provide opportunities for crop improvement. The expected outcomes are: A) the Tomato Expression Atlas (TEA), a gene expression database for cultivated tomato and wild relatives, and new insights into the regulatory circuitry that controls fruit development and responses to drought, at a cell/tissue type level of resolution; B) detailed information about the tissue specificity of hormone biosynthesis and signaling pathways, and cell wall biosynthesis and remodeling during fruit development in tomato and wild relatives, and following drought treatments. Public access to all data and biological materials will be through the Tomato Expression Atlas (TEA) website and long-term public repositories. All DNA sequences will be released to the public domain immediately after generation and quality control through Genbank (http://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov) and SGN (http://solgenomics.net). Raw RNA-Seq, sRNA-seq and BS-seq datasets generated under this project will be submitted to NCBI SRA (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra) for long term storage and public access while processed expression and methylation profiles will be archived and accessed through the TEA and through the Tomato Functional Genomics Database (http://solgenomics.net/ted) and the Tomato Epigenome database (http://ted.bti.cornell.edu/epigenome).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fleshy fruit represent unique plant developmental systems and constitute important components of human and animal diets. Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum), an economically important crop, has emerged as the principal model for studies of fleshy fruit development, ripening, shelf life and nutritional quality. However, many fundamental questions related to key aspects of the development, physiology, quality traits and environmental responses of fruit remain unanswered. This project focused on deciphering complex problems in plant biology that are also central to fleshy fruit development and quality. These included characterizing: (i) the network of regulatory genes, gene structures and proteins that influence fruit growth and ripening; (ii) a range of plant hormone biosynthesis and signaling pathways that are key factors in governing fruit development; and (iii) molecular events that result in the formation or breakdown of the cell walls of fruit, which are central to fruit expansion, texture, biomechanical strength and that provide protection from environmental stresses, such as drought and attack by pathogens.

A core accomplishment of this project was to define and functionally evaluate, at an unprecedented level of temporal and spatial resolution (i.e. in time and space), the spectrum of genes that are turned on, or expressed, during tomato fruit growth and ripening. Another target was to elucidate responses of fruit to drought, an increasing problem in crop production, in varieties of cultivated tomato, as well as wild relatives of tomato that show a high tolerance of water stress. The outcome of these studies has been a collections of data sets that both provide new biological information and highlight opportunities for crop improvement. These data were incorporated into a new queryable database, the ?Tomato Expression Atlas? (TEA), which was designed to display information at the cell/tissue-type scale of resolution in 2D, 3D formats. The TEA database has a novel visualization tool, together with options for generating statistically supported information high resolution maps of genes that are expressed together, which allowed the development of hypotheses regarding their function. The TEA is now a widely used community resource with thousands of users worldwide, including researchers and breeders, which has inspired similar databases for other plants, including crops.

Examples of discoveries that resulted from this project and that were enabled by this high-resolution gene expression analysis included:

-       new insights into sugar transport and signaling during fruit establishment, expansion and ripening.

-       identification of a gene and molecular mechanism that allows the formation of cutin, a polymer that is the major component of the plant cuticle (the waxy ?skin?) and that is critically important for avoiding desiccation and infection by microbes.

-       characterization of enzymes that are the major factors in breaking down polysaccharide polymers in the cell walls and regions that cement plant cells together during ripening, and consequently are key determinants of softening and commercial viability.

-       profiling of the suites of metabolic compounds that characterize different stages of tomato fruit development and that are fundamental to their taste and nutritional quality. Such profiles were developed for normally ripening tomato and contrasted with those of mutants that show abnormal ripening, as well as in fruit that were harvested under commercially relevant conditions.

-       discovery of coordinated gradients of ripening-related gene expression across various axes of the fruit, across multiple fruit tissues and through developmental time

-       delineation of the relationships between seeds and fleshy fruit tissue and the characterization of seed-dependent and seed-independent processes that are integral to the ripening program

-       new understanding of the significance and control of the process of methylation, a chemical modification that affects gene expression, during ripening

An important element of the project was to develop a strong education and training component. This took the form of two programs: (a) an annual Plant Genomics and Systems Biology Workshop, comprising a series of integrated ?technology modules? with both seminars and lab-based practical training in genome-scale (?omics?) analytical disciplines; and (b) a multi-level training course in Scientific Communication, providing guidance in both oral and written presentation skills. These involved undergraduate students, high school students and high school teachers, with particular emphasis on the participation of under-represented groups through the support of a network of Cornell programs. The program also included a professional development course related to identifying diverse pathways in career pursuits that are outside the traditional academic framework, including opportunities in the arena of non-profit organizations and foundation, media studies and education outreach, intellectual property pursuits, public-private partnerships and entrepreneurial development.
